newsitem.title: BELGIUM: MAGAZINE TO CAMPAIGN FOR BELGIAN SEX ABUSE VICTIMS.
newsitem.headline: MAGAZINE TO CAMPAIGN FOR BELGIAN SEX ABUSE VICTIMS.

text.p: The parents of dead and missing Belgian children will publish a magazine dedicated to keeping alive an investigation into the authorities' handling of child sex abuse and murder cases.

Patrick van Alphen, the editor designate, said in interviews published and broadcast on Sunday that the parents wanted the journal to keep a public probe of the police and justice authorities' handling of the cases going.
"Every major movement needs its own mouthpiece," van Alphen told Belgian radio.
The issue has shaken Belgium's political establishment and prompted public outrage, with hundreds of thousands of protestors taking to the streets.
The parents of the murdered, missing or abused children also wanted to ensure their cause would continue to get the media attention it deserved, van Alphen said.

Led by the Russo and Lejeune families, whose eight-year-old girls Julie and Melissa died at the hands of a gang led by convicted child rapist Marc Dutroux, the parents aim to launch the 20 franc ($0.60) magazine on March 15.
Van Alphen said the magazine would try to keep alive a public investigation, currently carried out by a parliamentary commission.
The Dutroux scandal erupted in August when first two sexually abused girls were rescued from a Dutroux house. Later the bodies of four others were found.
The authorities fear at least six other missing girls have been murdered by the gang.
In the course of the current investigation it became clear that various police forces had failed to coordinate their actions.

It also emerged that police had sloppily conducted investigations and searches. There were allegations of high-level police protection for Dutroux and his gang members -- allegations that are still being investigated.
Last year's revelations caused public outrage, culminating in a October 20 march in Brussels by 300,000 people voicing their lack of confidence in the law and order system.
The demonstration, dubbed the White March, has given its name to the magazine which will have articles written mainly by volunteers in Dutch and French.

The publication date coincides with the end of the mandate of so-called Dutroux commission and the magazine will "try to keep the movement going which saw the light on October 20, try to find a listening ear," Van Alphen said.
The parents have repeatedly complained about the lack of openness and sympathy from the authorities who, they said, paid more attention to the criminals than to the victim.
"The (White March) magazine is for all those people who have been turned away by the administration," Van Alphen said.
